sub_topic: Calculating the effect of changing the concentration of a salt on the solubility of a sparingly soluble salt
message_1: What is the effect on the solubility of silver chloride (AgCl) in water when the concentration of sodium chloride (NaCl) is increased in the solution? Calculate the new solubility of AgCl when a 0.1 M solution of NaCl is added to 100 mL of water containing 0.01 M AgCl.
message_2:
The solubility of silver chloride (AgCl) in water decreases when the concentration of sodium chloride (NaCl) is increased in the solution. This is due to the common ion effect, where the presence of a common ion (in this case, Cl-) in the solution reduces the solubility of a sparingly soluble salt (AgCl).

To calculate the new solubility of AgCl, we can use the solubility product constant (Ksp) and the concentrations of the ions in the solution.

The Ksp of AgCl is 1.77 x 10^-10. The balanced dissolution reaction for AgCl is:

AgCl (s) ⇌ Ag+ (aq) + Cl- (aq)

Initially, the solution contains 0.01 M AgCl and no NaCl. When 0.1 M NaCl is added, the Cl- concentration increases by 0.1 M. The new equilibrium concentrations will be:

[Ag+] = x
[Cl-] = 0.1 + x

Since Ksp = [Ag+][Cl-], we can set up the equation:

1.77 x 10^-10 = x(0.1 + x)

Assuming x is much smaller than 0.1 (which is reasonable given the low solubility of AgCl), we can approximate the equation as:

1.77 x 10^-10 ≈ x(0.1)

Now, solve for x:

x ≈ 1.77 x 10^-10 / 0.1
x ≈ 1.77 x 10^-9

The new solubility of AgCl in the presence of 0.1 M NaCl is approximately 1.77 x 10^-9 M.
